description: From Middle English lenen (“to lean”), from Old English hleonian, hlinian (“to lean, recline, lie down, rest”), from Proto-West Germanic *hlinēn, from Proto-Germanic *hlināną (“to lean, incline”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱley-.
Cognate via Proto-Germanic with Middle Dutch leunen (“to lean”), German lehnen (“to lean”); via Proto-Indo-European with climate, cline.

entries.meaning: (of an object taller than its width and depth) An inclination away from the vertical.
examples: The trees had various leans toward gaps in the canopy.

verbs.description: lean (third-person singular simple present leans, present participle leaning, simple past and past participle leaned or (UK) leant)

entries.meaning: To incline, deviate, or bend, from a vertical position; to be in a position thus inclining or deviating.
examples: She leaned out of the window.

entries.meaning: (copulative) To incline in opinion or desire; to conform in conduct; often with to, toward, etc.
examples: I’m leaning towards voting Conservative in the next election.

entries.meaning: Followed by against, on, or upon: to rest or rely, for support, comfort, etc.

description: From Middle English lene (“lean”), from Old English hlǣne (“lean”), (cognate with Low German leen), perhaps from hlǣnan (“to cause to lean (due to hunger or lack of food)”), from Proto-Germanic *hlainijaną (“to cause to lean”). If so, then related to Old English hlinian, hleonian (“to lean”).

entries.meaning: (of a person or animal) Slim; not fleshy.
examples: Synonyms: lithe, svelte, willowy; see also Thesaurus:slender

entries.meaning: Having little extra or little to spare; scanty; meagre.
examples: Synonyms: insufficient, scarce, sparse; see also Thesaurus:inadequate

entries.meaning: Having a low proportion or concentration of a desired substance or ingredient.
examples: A lean ore hardly worth mining.
Running on too lean a fuel-air mixture will cause, among other problems, your internal combustion engine to heat up too much.

entries.meaning: (printing, archaic) Of a character which prevents the compositor from earning the usual wages; opposed to fat.
(business) Efficient, economic, frugal, agile, slimmed-down; pertaining to the modern industrial principles of "lean manufacturing".
examples: Alcoa is now a lean and agile enterprise, after having split last year into two entities.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Meat with no fat on it.
examples: Jack Sprat would eat no fat, / His wife would eat no lean.

entries.meaning: (countable, biology) An organism that is lean in stature.
examples: The intermediates and leans are the predominant morphotypes found at the SE-NHR seamounts  […]

verbs.description: lean (third-person singular simple present leans, present participle leaning, simple past and past participle leaned)

entries.meaning: To thin out (a fuel-air mixture): to reduce the fuel flow into the mixture so that there is more air or oxygen.

description: From Icelandic leyna? Akin to German leugnen (“deny”). Compare lie (“speak falsely”).

verbs.description: lean (third-person singular simple present leans, present participle leaning, simple past and past participle leaned)

description: Probably from the verb to lean (see etymology 1 above), supposedly because consumption of the intoxicating beverage causes one to "lean". Alternatively, possibly short for gasoline (“an alcoholic beverage made of vodka and energy drink”).

entries.meaning: (slang, US) A recreational drug based on codeine-laced promethazine cough syrup, especially popular in the hip hop community in the southeastern United States.
